org.owasp.esapi.reference
Class FileBasedAuthenticator

railo-context.Component
        org.owasp.esapi.util.Object
            org.owasp.esapi.reference.FileBasedAuthenticator
All Implemented Interfaces:
Authenticator 
public class FileBasedAuthenticator

extends Object

Reference implementation of the Authenticator interface. This reference implementation is backed by a simple text file that contains serialized information about users. Many organizations will want to create their own implementation of the methods provided in the Authenticator interface backed by their own user repository. This reference implementation captures information about users in a simple text file format that contains user information separated by the pipe '|' character.

Method Detail

_createUser

private DefaultUser _createUser(String line)
Create a new user with all attributes from a String. The format is: [ accountId | accountName | password | roles (comma separated) | unlocked | enabled | old password hashes (comma separated) | last host address | last password change time | last long time | last failed login time | expiration time | failed login count ] This method verifies the account name and password strength, creates a new CSRF token, then returns the newly created user.

Parameters:
line - parameters to set as attributes for the new User.

_generateStrongPassword

private string _generateStrongPassword(String oldPassword)
Generate a strong password that is not similar to the specified old password.

Parameters:
oldPassword - the password to be compared to the new password for similarity

getAllHashedPasswords

public array getAllHashedPasswords(User user, boolean create)
Returns all of the specified User's hashed passwords. If the User's list of passwords is null, and create is set to true, an empty password list will be associated with the specified User and then returned. If the User's password map is null and create is set to false, an exception will be thrown.

Parameters:
user - the User whose old hashes should be returned
create - true - if no password list is associated with this user, create one; false - if no password list is associated with this user, do not create one

getCurrentUser

public User getCurrentUser()
Returns the currently logged user as set by the setCurrentUser() methods. Must not log in this method because the logger calls getCurrentUser() and this could cause a loop.

Specified by:
getCurrentUser in interface Authenticator

getHashedPassword

public string getHashedPassword(User user)
Return the specified User's current hashed password.

Parameters:
user - this User's current hashed password will be returned

getOldPasswordHashes

public array getOldPasswordHashes(User user)
Get a List of the specified User's old password hashes. This will not return the User's current password hash.

Parameters:
user - the user whose old password hashes should be returned

public any getUserFromRememberToken([HttpServletRequest httpRequest='[runtime expression]'], [HttpServletResponse httpResponse='[runtime expression]'])
Returns the user if a matching remember token is found, or null if the token is missing, token is corrupt, token is expired, account name does not match and existing account, or hashed password does not match user's hashed password.

setHashedPassword

public void setHashedPassword(User user, String hash)
Add a hash to a User's hashed password list. This method is used to store a user's old password hashes to be sure that any new passwords are not too similar to old passwords.

Parameters:
user - the user to associate with the new hash
hash - the hash to store in the user's password hash list

setOldPasswordHashes

public void setOldPasswordHashes(User user, Array oldHashes)
Set the specified User's old password hashes. This will not set the User's current password hash.

Parameters:
user - the User's whose old password hashes will be set
oldHashes - a list of the User's old password hashes

verifyAccountNameStrength

public void verifyAccountNameStrength(String accountName)
This implementation simply verifies that account names are at least 5 characters long. This helps to defeat a brute force attack, however the real strength comes from the name length and complexity.

Specified by:
verifyAccountNameStrength in interface Authenticator
Parameters:
accountName

verifyPassword

public boolean verifyPassword(User user, String password)

Specified by:
verifyPassword in interface Authenticator
Parameters:
user
password

verifyPasswordStrength

public void verifyPasswordStrength([String oldPassword], String newPassword, User user)
This implementation checks: - for any 3 character substrings of the old password - for use of a length character sets > 16 (where character sets are upper, lower, digit, and special

Specified by:
verifyPasswordStrength in interface Authenticator
Parameters:
oldPassword
newPassword
user
